00010 //  Win32 specific config options:
00011 
00012 #define BOOST_PLATFORM "Win32"
00013 
00014 #if defined(__GNUC__) && !defined(BOOST_NO_SWPRINTF)
00015 #  define BOOST_NO_SWPRINTF
00016 #endif
00017 
00018 #if !defined(__GNUC__) && !defined(BOOST_HAS_DECLSPEC)
00019 #  define BOOST_HAS_DECLSPEC
00020 #endif
00021 
00022 #if defined(__MINGW32__) && ((__GNUC__ > 3) || ((__GNUC__ == 3) && (__GNUC_MINOR__ >= 2)))
00023 #  define BOOST_HAS_STDINT_H
00024 #  define __STDC_LIMIT_MACROS
00025 #endif
00026 
00027 //
00028 // Win32 will normally be using native Win32 threads,
00029 // but there is a pthread library avaliable as an option,
00030 // we used to disable this when BOOST_DISABLE_WIN32 was 
00031 // defined but no longer - this should allow some
00032 // files to be compiled in strict mode - while maintaining
00033 // a consistent setting of BOOST_HAS_THREADS across
00034 // all translation units (needed for shared_ptr etc).
00035 //
00036 #ifndef BOOST_HAS_PTHREADS
00037 #  define BOOST_HAS_WINTHREADS
00038 #endif
00039 
00040 #ifndef BOOST_DISABLE_WIN32
00041 // WEK: Added
00042 #define BOOST_HAS_FTIME
00043 
00044 #endif
00045 
00046 //
00047 // disable min/max macros:
00048 //
00049 #ifdef min
00050 #  undef min
00051 #endif
00052 #ifdef max
00053 #  undef max
00054 #endif
00055 #ifndef NOMINMAX
00056 #  define NOMINMAX
00057 #endif
00058 
00059 #ifdef BOOST_MSVC
00060 #include <algorithm> // for existing std::min and std::max
00061 namespace std{
00062   // Apparently, something in the Microsoft libraries requires the "long"
00063   // overload, because it calls the min/max functions with arguments of
00064   // slightly different type.  (If this proves to be incorrect, this
00065   // whole "BOOST_MSVC" section can be removed.)
00066   inline long min(long __a, long __b) {
00067     return __b < __a ? __b : __a;
00068   }
00069   inline long max(long __a, long __b) {
00070     return  __a < __b ? __b : __a;
00071   }
00072   // The "long double" overload is required, otherwise user code calling
00073   // min/max for floating-point numbers will use the "long" overload.
00074   // (SourceForge bug #495495)
00075   inline long double min(long double __a, long double __b) {
00076     return __b < __a ? __b : __a;
00077   }
00078   inline long double max(long double __a, long double __b) {
00079     return  __a < __b ? __b : __a;
00080   }
00081 }
00082 using std::min;
00083 using std::max;
00084 #     endif
00085
